instruction: Can the pushbroom near infrared hyperspectral imaging (NIR-HSI) system be considered superior to traditional methods for ripening stage classification and dry matter prediction of durian pulp, based on the results of the related research?
Output: Based on the results of the related research, the pushbroom near infrared hyperspectral imaging (NIR-HSI) system can be considered superior to traditional methods for ripening stage classification and dry matter prediction of durian pulp. The research compared the performance of five supervised machine learning classifiers, including support vector machines (SVM), random forest (RF), linear discriminant analysis (LDA), partial least squares-discriminant analysis (PLS-DA), and k-nearest neighbors (kNN), for ripening stage classification. The LDA classifier showed the best result with a test accuracy of 100% for both full wavelength and selected wavelengths. Additionally, a partial least squares regression (PLSR) model was developed for dry matter prediction, achieving a coefficient of determination of prediction (Rp2) greater than 0.80 and a root mean square error of prediction (RMSEP) less than 1.6%. These results indicate that the NIR-HSI system has the potential to accurately classify ripening stages and predict dry matter content, making it superior to traditional methods for these purposes.
